titleStmt.title: Distributed Formation Control of Multiple Quadrotor Aircraft Based on Nonsmooth Consensus Algorithms

affiliation.orgName: School of Electrical Engineering and Automation
Department of Mechanics and Engineering Science
State Key Laboratory for Turbulence and Complex Systems
Academy of Mathematics and Systems Science

analytic.title: Distributed Formation Control of Multiple Quadrotor Aircraft Based on Nonsmooth Consensus Algorithms

biblStruct.note: received May 26, 2017; revised September 21, 2017; accepted November 13, 2017.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The problem of distributed formation control for multiple quadrotor aircraft in the form of leader-follower structure is considered in this paper. Based on a nonsmooth backstepping design, a novel consensus formation control algorithm is proposed and utilized. First, for the position control subsystem, based on the linear quadratic regulator optimal design method, a formation control law for multiple quadrotor aircraft is designed such that the positions of all the quadrotor aircraft converge to the desired formation pattern. The designed formation control law for position systems will generate the desired attitude for the attitude control systems. Second, for the attitude control subsystem described by unit quaternion, by employing the technique of finite-time control and switch control, a global bounded finite-time attitude tracking controller is designed such that the desired attitude can be tracked by the multiple quadrotor aircraft in finite time. Finally, numerical example is performed to demonstrate that all quadrotor aircraft converge to the desired formation pattern in the 3-D-space.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: A S A TYPICAL application of consensus/synchronization of complex network, the formation control problem of multiple quadrotor aircraft has got much attention from many research communities [1]- [7]. Due to the fact that the quadrotor aircraft has many special superiorities (e.g., small size, simple structure, rapid maneuverability, and vertical take offlanding), it is often used to perform a complex task in some dangerous environments, such as disaster monitoring, wilderness search and rescue, among many others [8]- [13]. This paper will consider the formation control problem for a group of quadrotor aircraft by using the consensus theory of complex network or multiagent systems.

Compared with a single quadrotor aircraft, the advantages of formation control of multiple quadrotor aircraft lie in the following aspects [7], [9], [14]- [17]. First, the total carrying capacity of aircraft can be improved which means that more devices or sensors can be equipped such that more difficult tasks can be achieved. Furthermore, the system stability and reliability can also be improved through the exchange of information among multiple aircraft. As both the control problem of a single quadrotor and the cooperative control problem among multiple quadrotor aircraft should be addressed, the formation controller design and stability analysis of formation achieving for multiple quadrotor aircraft will be much more difficult than controlling a single quadrotor aircraft.

Up to now, in order to achieve formation control of multiple quadrotor aircraft, a variety of control strategies have been proposed by researchers from various fields. In [9], an integral sliding mode control method was employed to design the controller for a quadrotor aircraft, where its application to formation control was also studied. In [18], a leader-following formation control strategy was proposed and analyzed. Based on the optimal control design method, a formation control algorithm was proposed in [19] to achieve the desired formation behaviors of multiple unmanned aerial vehicles. In [20], a behavior-based formation control algorithm was proposed and employed. Based on a virtual structure, a two-levels formation control algorithm was proposed in [21] for autonomous formations in 3-D. Based on a coordination architecture, the work [22] designed a formation controller for multiple spacecraft. To achieve collision avoidance, the work [23] constructed a distributed coordination controller by employing a bounded control technique for a group of quadrotor aircraft.
2168-2267 c 2017 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

Although many results about formation control of multiple quadrotor aircraft have been reported in existing literature, how to improve the control performance is still faced with certain challenge due to the inherent high-dimensional dynamics, nonlinear coupling among neighboring aircraft, etc. To this end and partly motivated by the work of [24]- [29], this paper will employ a nonsmooth consensus algorithm (protocol) to design a formation control algorithm for multiple quadrotor aircraft. It is worth noting that the nonsmooth controller itself is of interest as it can offer faster convergence speed and better ability of disturbance rejection compared with traditional smooth controllers [30]. However, within the context of formation control of multiple quadrotor aircraft, many difficulties of using nonsmooth control approach arise from the system's high nonlinear features. To conquer the difficulties, a nonsmooth backstepping method is proposed by skillfully exploiting the structural features of quadrotor model. Specifically, for the outer-loop, i.e., position control subsystem, the aircraft's attitude is taken as a virtual control signal based on the backstepping control approach. By using the design method of linear quadratic regulator (LQR) optimal control, a consensus formation control algorithm is proposed such that the multiple quadrotor aircraft asymptotically come into formation pattern and track the leader's trajectory. Then, for the inner-loop, i.e., attitude control subsystem, based on finite-time control technique, a finite-time attitude tracking control law is developed. By carefully choosing Lyapunov function, it is shown that the aircraft's attitude can converge to the desired attitude in finite time. Note that the inner-outerloop control strategy is one of the widely employed control methods for quadrotor aircraft, see [9], [11]- [13]. Under this kind of controllers, stability analysis of the closed-loop system is often performed based on backstepping control theory. Compared with the traditional backstepping-type controllers, the proposed nonsmooth controller-based backstepping design has the following advantages: 1) the controller is easy to construct and the subsequent stability analysis is relatively simple and 2) the convergence speed and disturbance rejection property for the attitude-loop can be enhanced by adjusting the additional parameters, i.e., the fractional powers.

The organization of this paper is given as follows. The mathematical model of multiple quadrotor aircraft and some preliminaries are provided in Section II. In Section III, the formation controller and attitude controller are, respectively, designed and utilized. In Section IV, the numerical simulation results are presented for illustration. At last, Section V concludes the whole work.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION AND PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Notation: Let R and C be the sets of real and complex numbers, respectively. R nÃn and C nÃn denote the sets of n Ã n real and complex matrices. Let I n â R nÃn be the n-dimensional identity matrix. Symbol 1 n â R n represents the vector with all entries be one. A = [a ij ] is a matrix with a ij being the entry of ith row and jth column. A = diag{a 1 , . . . , a n } represents a diagonal matrix with diagonal elements a 1 , . . . , a n .
x denotes the Euclidean norm of vector x.

div.head: A. Mathematical Model
div.p: Assume that there are n quadrotor aircraft (labeled from 1 to n) in the considered multiple aircraft systems. Set = {1, . . . , n}. To describe the motion and orientation of quadrotor aircraft, the coordinates with six variables including position and attitude variables are used as follows:
div.formula: (x i , y i , z i , Ï i , Î¸ i , Ï i ) T â R 6 , i â(1)
div.p: where
div.formula: P i = (x i , y i , z i ) â R 3
div.p: is the position of the center of mass with respect to an inertial coordinate frame, i = (Ï i , Î¸ i , Ï i ) T â R 3 are the Euler angles, i.e., roll, pitch, and yaw with respect to an inertial frame.
According to [12], the dynamic equation of position for the ith quadrotor aircraft is described by
div.formula: áºi = - T i m i (cos Ï i sin Î¸ i cos Ï i + sin Ï i sin Ï i ) Ã¿i = - T i m i (cos Ï i sin Î¸ i sin Ï i -sin Ï i cos Ï i ) zi = - T i m i cos Ï i cos Î¸ i + g, i â(2)
div.p: where m i represents the mass, g denotes the gravitational acceleration, T i represents the total thrust which is generated by the four rotors.

Next, we will give the dynamic equation for the attitude of quadrotor aircraft, where the quaternions attitude representation instead of Euler angles-based representation is employed to avoid the singularity problem [31]. Let q i = [q i,0 , q i,1 , q i,2 , q i,3 ] T = [q i,0 , q T i,v ] T â R 4 be the quaternion associated with the ith quadrotor aircraft, which can be obtained through the Euler angles according to the following equations:

div.head: B. Control Objectives
div.p: The main objective of this paper is to deign a distributed control law for a group of quadrotor aircraft to achieve:
1) desired formation pattern; 2) desired formation trajectory. Assume that the desired formation trajectory (x d , y d , z d ) is generated by

div.head: D. Communication Topology
div.p: The communication topology among n quadrotor aircraft is described by a directed graph G(A) = {V, E, A}. V = {v i , i = 1, . . . , n} is the set of nodes (quadrotor aircraft), E â V Ã V is the set of edges and A = [a ij ] â R nÃn is the weighted adjacency matrix of the graph G with non-negative adjacency elements a ij . If there is an edge between node i and node j, i.e., (v i , v j ) â E, then a ij > 0, which means there exists an available information channel from node j to node i. Moreover, assume that a ii = 0 for all i â . The set of neighbors of node v i is denoted by
div.formula: N i = {j : (v i , v j ) â E}. The out-degree of node v i is defined as deg out (v i ) = d i = n j=1 a ij = jâN i a ij . The degree matrix of digraph G(A) is defined as D = diag{d 1 , . . . , d n } and the Laplacian matrix of digraph G(A) is given by L = D -A, that is, L = â â â â â â â â â jâN 1 a 1j -a 12 . . . -a 1n -a 21 jâN 2 a 2j . . . -a 2n . . . . . . . . . -a n1 -a n2 . . . jâN n a nj â â â â â â â â â . A path in the directed graph G(A) from node v i 1 to node v i k is a sequence of v i 1 , v i 2 , . . . , v i k of finite nodes starting with v i 1 and ending by v i k such that (v i l , v i l+1 ) â E for l = 1, 2, . . . , k -1.
div.p: If there is a root node which can be connected to any others through paths, then the directed graph G(A) is said to have a spanning tree. IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CYBERNETICS

The reference attitude is denoted by a virtual leader. Let b i , i â represent the connection weight between the ith quadrotor aircraft and the leader. Note that b i > 0 if the ith aircraft has access to the information of leader and b i = 0 otherwise. For convenience, set B = diag{b 1 , . . . , b n }.
Assumption 1: The directed communication graph G has a spanning tree with the root node having access to the information of the virtual leader.
Lemma 3 [1]: With Assumption 1, all the eigenvalues of the matrix L + B have positive real parts.
Assumption 2: It is assumed that the pitch, roll, and yaw angles of quadrotor aircraft satisfy the following conditions:

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: The design of formation controller is based on an integrated method by using backstepping control and finite-time control, which is divided into the following two steps.

1) For the position subsystem (2), using the design method of LQR optimal control and considering the real attitude i as the virtual input, a consensus formation control law is designed such that all quadrotor aircraft come into formation pattern and move along the desired trajectory asymptotically.

2) For the attitude subsystem (5), using the technique of finite-time control, an attitude control law is designed such that the desired quaternion q d i can be tracked by the real quaternion q i in finite time.

div.head: A. Design of Position Controller
div.p: According to the position dynamical equation (2), define the virtual control inputs as follows:
div.formula: U i,x = - T i m i (cos Ï i sin Î¸ i cos Ï i + sin Ï i sin Ï i ) U i,y = - T i m i (cos Ï i sin Î¸ i sin Ï i -sin Ï i cos Ï i ) U i,z = - T i m i cos Ï i cos Î¸ i + g, i â . (16

div.p: As a result, for any i, j â

div.p: The formation behaviors of position dynamics for the multiple quadrotor aircraft along y-axis and z-axis can be analyzed, respectively, by performing some similar steps as those given above which are omitted for brevity.

Remark 1: Clearly, the proposed formation control law in Theorem 1 is distributed as the feedback information for each quadrotor aircraft is based only on the information of its neighbors and itself. The superiorities of distributed control strategy lie in its greater efficiency, higher robustness, and less communication requirement as shown in [1] and [2].

Remark 2: Note that the attitude is taken as a virtual control signal in the position-loop subsystem and a consensus algorithm is designed such that the formation can be achieved. Based on the idea of backstepping method, once the virtual control signal is determined, the next step is to design the control torque such that the virtual attitude (also called desired attitude for the attitude-loop) can be tracked by the real attitude asymptotically. However, it can be seen from the proof of Theorem 1 that it will be quite complex for the formation analysis of the closed-loop systems if the attitude system is simultaneously considered. To facilitate the formation analysis of the closed-loop systems, a simplified backstepping design is used, where in the second step, the technique of finite-time control is employed to design tracking controller such that the desired attitude can be tracked by the real attitude in finite time.

div.head: B. Design of Attitude Controller
div.p: In this section, with Assumption 2, we will design the attitude controller for the multiple quadrotor aircraft such that the desired attitude is tracked by the real attitude of quadrotor aircraft in finite time. The desired attitude is generated as follows:
div.formula: U i,x = - T d i m i cos Ï d i sin Î¸ d i cos Ï d i + sin Ï d i sin Ï d i U i,y = - T d i m i cos Ï d i sin Î¸ d i sin Ï d i -sin Ï d i cos Ï d i U i,z = - T d i m i cos Ï d i cos Î¸ d i + g, i â
div.p: one gets that
div.formula: T d i = m U 2 i,x + U 2 i,y + g -U i,z 2 Ï d i = arcsin -m U i,x sin Ï d i -U i,y cos Ï d i T i Î¸ d i = arctan - U i,x cos Ï d i + U i,y sin Ï d i g -U i,z , i â .
div.p: For the ith quadrotor, it follows from (3) that the desired quaternion attitude is
div.formula: q d i = [q d i,0 , (q d i,v ) T ] T = [q d i,0 , q d i,1 , q d i,2 , q d i,3 ] T â R 4 .
div.p: Furthermore, it can be obtained the desired angular velocity d i â R 3 satisfying
div.formula: qd i = 1 2 E q d i d i , i â . (32
div.p: To achieve the attitude tracking control problem, as that in [31], for ith aircraft, define e i = [e i,0 , e T i,v ] T â R 4 as the relative quaternion attitude error between the attitude q i and the desired attitude q d i . That is, e i,0 = q i,0 q d i,0 + q T i,v q d i,v e i,v = q d i,0 q i,vq i,0 q d i,vq dÃ i,v q i,v . (
The relative angular velocity error is defined as
div.formula: f i = f i,1 , f i,2 , f i,3 T = i -R b d (e i ) d i â R 3 (34
div.p: where R b d (e i ) is a rotation matrix from the desired reference frame to the body reference frame and is given by
div.formula: R b d (e i ) = R(q i )R T (q d i ) with R(q i,0 , q i,v ) = I 3Ã3 +2(q Ã i,v ) 2 -2q i,0 q Ã i,v .
div.p: With the above notations in mind, by [31], the dynamical equation for the relative attitude error system is obtained as

) Since i = f i + R b d (e i ) d i (37
div.p: one may get that
div.formula: J á¸i = -Ã i J i i + Ï i -J i R b d (e i ) Ë d i + J i f Ã i R b d (e i ) d i = -f Ã i J i i -R b d (e i ) d i Ã J i f i + R b d (e i ) d i + Ï i -J i R b d (e i ) Ë d i + J i f Ã i R b d (e i ) d i = -f Ã i J i i -R b d (e i ) d i Ã J i f i + J i f Ã i R b d (e i ) d i + Ï i -R b d (e i ) d i Ã J i R b d (e i ) d i -J i R b d (e i ) Ë d i = -f Ã i J i i -R b d (e i ) d i Ã J i f i -J i R b d (e i ) d i Ã f i + Ï i -R b d (e i ) d i Ã J i R b d (e i ) d i -J i R b d (e i ) Ë d i . (38
div.p: As a result, to achieve the finite-time attitude tracking, we only need to design an attitude controller such that e i,v â 0, f i â 0 in finite time. Before moving on, the following definitions are introduced.
Definition 2 [33]: Denote function sig Î± (x) = sign(x)|x| Î± , where Î± > 0, x â R, sign(â¢) is a standard sign function. For any given
div.formula: x = [x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ] T â R n , set sig Î± (x) = [sig Î± (x 1 ), sig Î± (x 2 ), . . . , sig Î± (x n )] T .
div.p: Definition 3 [35]:
div.formula: Let sat Î± (x) = sign(x), for |x| > 1 sig Î± (x), for |x| â¤ 1 (39
div.p: where Î± > 0, x â R. For any given
div.formula: x = [x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ] T â R n , define sat Î± (x) = [sat Î± (x 1 ), sat Î± (x 2 ), . . . , sat Î± (x n )] T .
div.p: Remark 3: The saturation function defined in (39) is sightly different with those commonly employed in some existing literature. Here, the aim of introducing such a new kind of saturation function is to design a class of bounded finite-time attitude tracking controller to avoid the saturation constraint in practice.
Theorem 2: Suppose that Assumption 2 holds and the controller torque is designed as
div.formula: Ï i = â§ âª âª âª âª âª â¨ âª âª âª âª âª â© -Î² 1 e i,v + Î² 2 sat(f i ) + R b d (e i ) d i Ã J i R b d (e i ) d i + J i R b d (e i ) Ë d i , |e i,0 | â¤ 1 2 -Î² 1 G e i,v T sat Î± 1 e i,v -Î² 2 sat Î± 2 (f i ) + J i R b d (e i ) Ë d i + R b d (e i ) d i Ã J i R b d (e i ) d i , |e i,0 | > 1 2 (40)
div.p: with
. Then, the relative attitude errors will converge to zero vector in finite time, i.e., e i,v â 0, f i â 0 in finite time, where e i,v and f i are, respectively, defined in (33) and (34).

The detailed proof of this Theorem 2 is included in the Appendix. For the attitude-loop subsystem, the finite-time attitude control algorithm is designed such that the desired attitude can be tracked in finite time. This means that there is a finite time T * such that q i = q d i , and
div.formula: i = (Ï i , Î¸ i , Ï i ) T = d i = (Ï d i , Î¸ d i , Ï d i )
div.p: T for all t â¥ T * . Combining with the results provided in Theorem 1, one gets that the formation control problem is solved by the designed controller.

Remark 4: Note that the present attitude control torque is a kind of nonsmooth controller. The designed attitude control torque is of practical interest due to its advantages of fast convergence rate and good disturbance rejection property. Furthermore, the parameters Î± 1 , Î± 2 can be seen as tunable parameters. Generally, in order to reduce the bounds of steady output errors, the control gains are required to selected sufficiently large from the conventional disturbance controller design. However, it is well-known that high gain feedback control system often leads to instability in close-loop systems in practice. Hence, a kind of nonsmooth controller based on saturation function (39) is designed in this paper. It is important to note as well that one can reduce the bounds of steady output errors by adjusting the fractional powers Î± 1 , Î± 2 , rather than increasing the control gains.
Remark 5: It should be noted that, for ith quadrotor aircraft, the practical control inputs are four motors' speed rather than the total thrust T i and attitude control torque
). The transform relationship between motors' speed and motors' torque can be found in [36].

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS
div.p: Numerical simulations are performed in this section to verify the previous analytical analysis.

Consider the distributed control problem for a formation flying with three quadrotor aircraft described by ( 2)-( 5). The communication topology among these three quadrotor aircraft is described by a directed graph as shown in Fig. 1. The weights of the directed edges are, respectively, given as: graph shown in Fig. 1 is calculated as follows:
div.formula: a 12 = a 13 = 0, a 21 = 1, a 23 = 0, a 31 = 0, a 32 = 1, and b 1 = 1, b 2 = b 3 = 0. The Laplacian matrix of the directed
div.p: The inertia matrices of quadrotor aircraft are given as follows: J 1 = diag{0.0049, 0.0049, 0.0088} and J 2 = J 3 = diag{0.0023, 0.0024, 0.0026}. The reference formation trajectory is generated by a virtual leader quadrotor whose trajectory is given as: x d = 0.2t, y d = 0.2t, and z d = 0.2t. The desired formation pattern is chosen as a regular triangle in the xy plane as that in Fig. 1, where the radius of the circle is r = 1 and the desired position deviations are
The initial conditions for positions of quadrotor aircraft are, respectively, given as
The control gains are chosen as follows: where the parameters c, k 1 , and k 2 are selected based on the conditions provided in Theorem 1 with Q = I 2 and R = 1.

Case 1 (Formation Control in the Absence of External Disturbances): In this case, the nonsmooth control-based formation control algorithms ( 17) and (40) are designed and utilized. The response curves of formation flying of the three quadrotor aircraft are, respectively, shown in Figs. 2 and3, from which it can be found that all the quadrotor aircraft converge to the desired formation pattern and move along the desired trajectory. Figs. 4 and5 provide the response curves for the position and linear velocity of each quadrotor aircraft, respectively. The attitude and angular velocity of each quadrotor aircraft are, respectively, given in Figs. 6 and7.

The performance comparisons in terms of convergence time of the designed controller with Î± 1 = Î± 2 = 1 and Î± 1 = 2/5, Î± 2 = 4/7 are further numerically studied. Under the condition that Î± 1 = Î± 2 = 1, the present finite-time controller will reduce to the asymptotical controller with only asymptotic II.

It can be found that, by regulating the additional parameters, i.e., the fractional powers Î± 1 and Î± 2 , the steady-state errors of output signals can be reduced. However, it should be pointed out that, from another viewpoint, i.e., the smooth of control input signals, the control signals will be more and more chattered if (Î± 1 , Î± 2 ) â (0, 0). Hence, in practice, a tradeoff between the system performance and the quality of control signals has to be made.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: Distributed formation flying control problem for a group of quadrotor aircraft under leader-following structure has been studied in this paper. Based on the LQR optimal control and finite-time control theory, a new kind of distributed nonsmooth control-based formation control algorithm has been developed. Theoretical analysis has shown that that all the quadrotor aircraft can converge to the desired formation pattern and track the desired formation trajectory. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method has been verified through performing numerical simulations. Future work will focus on solving the distributed formation flying control problem of multiple quadrotor aircraft with unreliable communication environment as well as formation flying control problem of unmanned systems under directed switching topology.

div.head: APPENDIX PROOF OF THEOREM 2
div.p: There are two cases for the initial state e i,0 , i.e., |e i,0 | â¤ (1/2) and |e i,0 | > (1/2).
Case 1: We first consider the case with |e i,0 | â¤ (1/2) and prove that the state e i,0 will enter the region |e i,0 | > (1/2) in finite time. Consider the following Lyapunov function:

Case 2: For the case with |e i,0 | > (1/2), we will prove that the attitude error (e i,v , f i ) will converge to zero vector in finite time. Substituting the proposed control law (40) into systems (35) and (38) leads to the closed-loop system as follows:

div.p: Performing some similar proof procedures as those in step 1) leads to that system (58) is asymptotically stable, i.e., (e i,v , f i ) â 0 as t â 0. Meanwhile, it can be verified from Definition 1 that system (58) is homogeneous of degree k = (Î± 1 -1)/2 < 0 with respect to r 1 = 1, r 2 = (Î± 1 + 1)/2, where 0 < Î± 1 < 1, Î± 2 = 2Î± 1 /(1 + Î± 1 ).

Next, it will be shown that the nonlinear part of system (57) satisfies the condition of Lemma 1, i.e., lim Îµâ0 ([g 1 (Îµ r 1 e i,v , Îµ r 2 f i )]/[Îµ r 1 +k ]) = 0 and lim Îµâ0 ([g 2 (Îµ r 1 e i,v , Îµ r 2 f i )]/[Îµ r 2 +k ]) = 0, for any (e i,v , f i ) = 0. Since the function G(Îµ r 1 e i,v ) is a continuously differentiable function, then G(Îµ r 1 e i,v ) -G(0) = O(Îµ r 1 e i,v ) by using the mean value inequality.
Hence, for any (e i,v , f i ) = 0, the following equalities hold:
